<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 118, 379, 144]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 170, 183, 187]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 194, 332, 210]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Multiple Choice (Core)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[784, 170, 905, 186]]<|/det|>
0625/13  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[784, 194, 905, 210]]<|/det|>
May/June 2021  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[814, 217, 905, 231]]<|/det|>
45 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 247, 507, 263]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 277, 437, 293]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[215, 291, 539, 320]]<|/det|>
Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 337, 228, 352]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 354, 115, 368]]<|/det|>
<label>+</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[129, 354, 601, 370]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 369, 907, 400]]<|/det|>
For each question there are four possible answers \(\mathbf{A}\) , \(\mathbf{B}\) , \(\mathbf{C}\) and \(\mathbf{D}\) . Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 400, 579, 415]]<|/det|>
Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 416, 277, 431]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 431, 868, 462]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 462, 327, 476]]<|/det|>
Do not use correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 477, 364, 492]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 492, 329, 507]]<|/det|>
You may use a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 507, 670, 523]]<|/det|>
Take the weight of \(1.0\mathrm{kg}\) to be \(10\mathrm{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10\mathrm{m / s}^2\) ).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 550, 220, 564]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 566, 540, 616]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 40. Each correct answer will score one mark. Any rough working should be done on this question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[268, 848, 728, 865]]<|/det|>
This document has 20 pages. Any blank pages are indicated.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 532, 89]]<|/det|> The diagram shows a plastic rod alongside a ruler. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[299, 100, 695, 185]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 198, 363, 216]]<|/det|> What is the length of the rod? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 227, 134, 245]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 227, 208, 245]]<|/det|> 2.5 cm <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 227, 298, 245]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 227, 376, 245]]<|/det|> 3.5 cm <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 227, 467, 245]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[470, 227, 544, 245]]<|/det|> 7.0 cm <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 227, 636, 245]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[648, 227, 680, 245]]<|/det|> 9.0 cm <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 272, 92, 291]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 272, 910, 291]]<|/det|> Two stones of different weights fall at the same time from a table. Air resistance may be ignored. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 303, 346, 320]]<|/det|> What will happen and why? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 330, 930, 460]]<|/det|>
what will happenwhy
ABoth stones hit the floor at the same time.Acceleration of free fall is constant.
BBoth stones hit the floor at the same time.They fall at constant speed.
CThe heavier stone hits the floor first.Acceleration increases with weight.
DThe heavier stone hits the floor first.Speed increases with weight.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 855, 89]]<|/det|> Diagram 1 shows a sealed plastic bottle containing a hollow glass sphere and a steel ball. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 603, 120]]<|/det|> Diagram 2 shows the same bottle after it has been shaken. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 131, 920, 166]]<|/det|> Diagram 3 shows the same bottle after it has been shaken again until the broken glass is in tiny pieces. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 175, 925, 330]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 342, 574, 361]]<|/det|> The mass of the bottle and contents in diagram 1 is \(m_{1}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 371, 574, 390]]<|/det|> The mass of the bottle and contents in diagram 2 is \(m_{2}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 401, 574, 420]]<|/det|> The mass of the bottle and contents in diagram 3 is \(m_{3}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 432, 675, 451]]<|/det|> Which statement gives the correct relation between \(m_{1}, m_{2}\) and \(m_{3}\)? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 460, 134, 479]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 460, 480, 479]]<|/det|> \(m_{1}\) is equal to \(m_{2}\) and \(m_{2}\) is equal to \(m_{3}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 488, 133, 505]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 488, 549, 507]]<|/det|> \(m_{1}\) is greater than \(m_{2}\) and \(m_{2}\) is greater than \(m_{3}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 515, 133, 533]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 514, 524, 533]]<|/det|> \(m_{1}\) is less than \(m_{2}\) and \(m_{2}\) is greater than \(m_{3}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 541, 133, 559]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 541, 500, 559]]<|/det|> \(m_{1}\) is less than \(m_{2}\) and \(m_{2}\) is less than \(m_{3}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 584, 96, 602]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 583, 720, 602]]<|/det|> The table shows the weight of a \(15.0\mathrm{kg}\) mass placed on different planets. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 612, 613, 631]]<|/det|> Which planet has a gravitational field strength of \(11.1 \text{N / kg}\)? planetweight of 15.0 kg mass / N

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 368, 581, 387]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 399, 650, 418]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 428, 133, 446]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 428, 482, 446]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 454, 366, 472]]<|/det|>

<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 500, 571, 518]]<|/det|>
A stream flows out of a lake and down the side of a hill.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 530, 532, 549]]<|/det|>
What best describes the change in energy stores?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 560, 133, 579]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 560, 579, 579]]<|/det|>
kinetic energy \(\rightarrow\) chemical energy + internal energy

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 588, 133, 606]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 588, 680, 606]]<|/det|>
gravitational potential energy \(\rightarrow\) kinetic energy + internal energy

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 615, 131, 633]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 615, 680, 633]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 642, 680, 660]]<|/det|>
kinetic energy \(\rightarrow\) internal energy + gravitational potential energy

The box does not move because an object is in the way. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 147, 480, 165]]<|/det|> Man Y lifts box Q from the floor onto a shelf. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 173, 902, 350]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 363, 808, 382]]<|/det|> Which man does the most work on their box, and which box gains the most energy? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 393, 452, 539]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 440, 106, 459]]<|/det|>
<label>14</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 440, 304, 459]]<|/det|>
A car tyre contains air.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 470, 887, 489]]<|/det|>
The temperature of the air in the tyre rises. The volume of the air in the tyre remains constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 500, 920, 534]]<|/det|>
Students are asked to suggest how this temperature rise will affect the movement of the air molecules.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 545, 510, 564]]<|/det|>
1 The air molecules will move faster.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 572, 640, 591]]<|/det|>
2 The air molecules will hit the tyre walls more often.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 597, 606, 616]]<|/det|>
3 The air molecules will hit the tyre walls harder.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 628, 378, 645]]<|/det|>
Which suggestions are correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 655, 134, 673]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 655, 240, 673]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 655, 300, 673]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[310, 655, 425, 673]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 655, 470, 673]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[648, 655, 761, 673]]<|/det|>

<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 571, 500, 588]]<|/det|>
water molecules being hit by pollen grains

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 615, 106, 632]]<|/det|>
<label>16</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 615, 808, 632]]<|/det|>
The liquid level in a thermometer rises when the thermometer is placed in hot water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 644, 272, 662]]<|/det|>
What causes this?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 673, 134, 691]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 673, 320, 691]]<|/det|>
The liquid contracts.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 700, 134, 717]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>39</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 72, 668, 89]]<|/det|>
A student is investigating the count rate of a radioactive substance.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 102, 598, 120]]<|/det|>
How must he adjust his reading for the background count?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 130, 134, 147]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 129, 494, 147]]<|/det|>
Add the background count to his reading.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 156, 131, 174]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 155, 643, 174]]<|/det|>
Ignore the background count as it will not affect his reading.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 183, 131, 201]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 183, 551, 201]]<|/det|>
